choices.text:
what is a metonymy?
Metonymy is a figure of speech in which the name of one thing is used to refer to something else with which it is closely associated. For example, "Washington" can be used as a shorthand for the federal government or political establishment in general. It differs from synecdoche, another type of metaphorical substitution, where only part of an object or concept is referred to instead of the whole thing.
